message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest Polyarteritis nodosa, which affects medium-sized arteries and causes systemic symptoms including muscle pain, weight loss, and abdominal and chest pain. The ulcers around the ankle and calves suggest cutaneous involvement. The negative perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies rules out Granulomatosis with polyangiitis. The other options are less likely given the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a systemic vasculitis, and the muscle biopsy shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis, which is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa. The ulcerations around the ankle and calves also support this diagnosis. None of the other options have these specific findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, muscle biopsy results, and negative anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies suggest a diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa. Giant cell arteritis and granulomatosis with polyangiitis usually have positive anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, and thromboangiitis obliterans usually presents with peripheral arterial disease and smoking history. The presence of chronic hepatitis B infection may be a risk factor for polyarteritis nodosa.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, muscle biopsy showing transmural inflammation of arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis, and negative anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies suggest Polyarteritis nodosa. The other options are less likely causes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which is characterized by inflammation of medium-sized arteries. Patients with PAN often present with weight loss, muscle pain, and abdominal pain. The ulcerations around the ankle and calves suggest vascular involvement. Urinalysis shows proteinuria and hematuria, which is common in PAN. The muscle biopsy findings are consistent with vasculitis. Giant cell arteritis affects large and medium-sized arteries, granulomatosis with polyangiitis affects small- to medium-sized arteries, and thromboangiitis obliterans affects small arteries and veins.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely diagnosis is Polyarteritis nodosa. The patient had diffuse muscle pain, weight loss, intermittent abdominal and chest pain, ulceration on both ankles and calves, and hematuria. The muscle biopsy showed transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis. All other options involve inflammation in smaller blood vessels rather than transmural inflammation of arterial walls.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, muscle biopsy findings, and presence of chronic hepatitis B infection suggest the most likely diagnosis is Polyarteritis nodosa, which can be associated with chronic hepatitis B infection. All other options are less likely based on the presented symptoms and biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of diffuse muscle pain, malaise, joint pain, weight loss, and skin ulcerations suggests polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). The muscle biopsy also shows evidence of transmural inflammation of the arterial wall, which is a hallmark of PAN. The other options do not fit the patient’s symptoms and findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including diffuse muscle pain, weight loss, and abdominal and chest pain suggest Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). The presence of ulcerations and proteinuria and hematuria are also common in PAN. The other options would not present with all these symptoms, and their respective laboratory findings and diagnostic tests would differ from those presented in the question.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a systemic vasculitis, and muscle biopsy shows transmural inflammation of the arterial wall, which is common in Polyarteritis nodosa. The ulcers around the ankle and calves also suggest this diagnosis. The other options do not fit the symptoms as well.
